Info.title: How to Make a Complex Rest API using Angular, Django and PostgreSQL
Info.desc: Explains the process of setting up an Angular frontend with a Django Rest API backend.

Instructions.instruction: We'll build a full-stack web application step-by-step using Angular, Python, Django, and Postgres.
A full video demo of this app can be found on my YouTube channel [here](FILL THIS IN).
Let's get started!

Info.title: Technologies We'll Use
Info.desc: This is the techstack we'll use to make this project

Instructions.instruction: Angular - The JavaScript Framework we'll use to build our user interface.
JavaScript - The scripting language we'll use to add logic to our frontend.
Django - The Python web framework we'll use to help build our Rest Api.
Python - The programming language we'll use to develop our Rest Api.
SQL - The language we'll use to help build and query our database.
PostgreSQL - The database we'll use to store user information.
Visual Studio Code - The code editor we'll use to help us build our project.
PyTest - The Python testing framework we'll use to test our Rest Api.
Jasmine - The built-in Angular testing framework we'll use to test our frontend code.
Github - The platform we'll use for version control and collaborative software development.
Git - The distributed version control system we'll use to track changes to our projects.
Homebrew - MacOS package manager we'll use to install software. Optional to use.

Info.title: Setup Technologies
Info.desc: Explanation of how to setup and verify all technologies.

Instructions.instruction: Verify you have visual studio Code installed by running the following command in a terminal. If it outputs a version number you should have it installed.
If you haven't already download Visual Studio Code [Here](https://code.visualstudio.com/download). Download the version that matches your operating system.
Verify that you have Homebrew installed on your computer by running this command in your terminal. If it outputs a version you should have it installed.
If you don't already have homebrew installed, install it using the following command.
Verify that you have node and npm installed by running the following commands. If they output a version you should be good.
If node and npm didn't output a version, download them using homebrew. It's just one command.
Verify that you have Python3 installed.
If you don't have Python3 installed, download it [here](https://www.python.org/downloads/)
Install the following Python libraries

Code.FormatCode:
pip3 install django
pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-html
Code.CopyCode:
pip3 install django
pip3 install pytest
pip3 install pytest-html

Instructions.instruction: Verify you have the Python packages installed by running the following commands. If it doesn't produce a "WARNING: Package(s) not found" error, you should be good.

Code.FormatCode:
pip3 show django
pip3 show pytest
Code.CopyCode:
pip3 show django
pip3 show pytest

Instructions.instruction: Go to [github.com](https://github.com/) to see if you have an account. If you don't press the "Sign Up" button in the top-right and follow the prompts.
Verify that git is installed by running the following command in a terminal. If it outputs a version you're good.
If you don't have git setup follow this instruction set (here)[/CompSci/GitHub#createGHAccount].
Verify that you have PostgreSQL installed by running the following command.
If the command in step 17 didn't output the version, see the next steps titled "How to Install PostgreSQL". Follow the instruction set that corresponds to your operating system.

Info.title: How to Install PostgreSQL
Info.desc: Explains how to install PostgreSQL on MacOS.

Instructions.instruction: Go [here](https://www.postgresql.org/download/) to see the instructions for how to download PostgreSQL. Press on the card that has the logo of your operating system. For mac you would just install it using the following commands. Make sure to upgrade brew first.

Code.FormatCode:
brew install pkg-config
brew upgrade gh
brew upgrade
brew install postgresql@15
Code.CopyCode:
brew install pkg-config
brew upgrade gh
brew upgrade
brew install postgresql@15

Instructions.instruction: If you get an error that says "error: externally-managed-environment" when you try to run pip3 after upgrading brew, I'd honestly just recommend downloading the latest version of python [here](https://www.python.org/downloads/). Ignore the suggested fixes.
Add PostgreSQL to your PATH
Verify that you have PostgreSQL installed by running the following command.
If step 21 didn't work your path might be wrong. Run the following command and look for the echo command in the output.
If step 21 didn't work, open your ~/.zshrc file by running the following command and then delete the old path. Then press control + o, return/enter, control + x to save your changes
If step 21 didn't work, run the following command to source your file. Then check that psql is installed.

Info.title: Design Your Database Schema
Info.desc: The first thing we'll do is design our database ER and Schema diagrams.

Instructions.instruction: We'll be creating a notes app. We'll have users that each have their own set of notes. Each note will have it's individual attributes.

To design our diagrams we'll use [erdplus.com](https://erdplus.com/). We used this tool in CSC 455 (now CSC 355) so you should be able to login using your UNCW credentials. Go to the "Documents" tab to create your diagram.

This will be our &Schema Diagram&(/download/NotesSchema.png). Go to the "Documents" tab to create your diagram. Then name your diagram and select "Relational Schema". When you finished press "Menu" in the top-left. Select "High Resolution (4x normal size)" and then press Save. NOTE: I'm not 100% sure if this diagram is completely accurate.

This will be our &ER Diagram&(/download/NotesSchema.png). Go to the "Documents" tab to create your diagram. Then name your diagram and select "ER Diagram". When you finished press "Menu" in the top-left. Select "High Resolution (4x normal size)" and then press Save. NOTE: I'm not 100% sure if this diagram is completely accurate.

Info.title: Setup PostgreSQL Database
Info.desc: We'll Setup our PostgreSQL database for our project on MacOS.

Instructions.instruction: Each user in your group will have to setup PostgreSQL on their own computer.
Make sure every user has Postgres installed using the following command to confirm it's installed. If they don't have it installed, follow instructions in the "How to Install PostgreSQL" section

Now you'll start your Postgres server. First list your brew services. If the status of Postgres is "None" than means your server is NOT running. Copy and record the name of your postgresql database. Mine was "postgresql@15".
If your server isn't running, start it using the following command. Replace "postgresql@15" with the name from the previous command if it's different.
Initialize the database cluster using the following command.
Run the following command to confirm your cluster started. If the "status" says running you should be good.
Login as superuser. You don't have to change any part of the command.
Run the following command to see your username.
Run the following command to your list of roles and permissions. Press 'q' to exit.
Create your databases. There will be a production database and a test database. Press 'q' to exit.

Code.FormatCode:

CREATE DATABASE notesapp_test_db;

CREATE DATABASE notesapp_test_db;

Now create your users. You will have a super user named "postgres" and a regular user and test user. You can change the usernames and passwords as you wish.
Now run the following command. You should see your new user in your database.
Now exit your Postgres session.
Now test that your URI is working. This isn't a command but this is what it should look like.
Now run the following command in your terminal to test your endpoint.
Now ping your test database.

Instructions.instruction: If steps 7 and 8 worked, you should be good.
Now go back to [github.com](https://github.com/) and open your "Notes-Rest-Api" repository. You're going to add your team-members as collaborators.
Click on the "Settings" tab on the right with the gear icon next to it.

On the left-hand bar press on "Collaborators". Then press the green "Add people" tab. In the search bar look up the Github usernames of each of your team members. After you find them press the green "Add *username* to this repository".
After you send the invite tell your team members to check their email. Press the "View invitation" link in the email, then accept on GitHub.
Add them for both your Rest api and frontend repositories.
After that you should be good

Info.title: Django Rest API Folder Setup Explanation
Info.desc: Explains the purpose of the various folders and what code they should contain.

Instructions.instruction: api/errors - Where the custom exceptions for your project will be kept.
api/models - Python classes that represent the objects in your database.
api/repositories - All functions that will be used to query and "talk to" your database. These should just be your simple sql queries. Your business logic will be applied in the "services" folder.

api/routes - Where your endpoints will be stored. All data returned from this Rest API will happen in this folder. The logic and functions you use to "talk to" your database should be in your "services" and "repositories" folder. Keep your endpoint functions short and clean.

api/schemas - Serializes and deserializes JSON data using the python "Marshmellow" library. Basically it will take a JSON object response and convert it into a Python model object. It will also do the opposite and convert a Python model object into a JSON object.
api/services - Functions that use your repository functions to create business logic in your application.
api/utils - Common functions that are reused in various parts of your Rest API.
tests/db_testing - Where you'll test your database connection.
tests/endpoint_testing - Test your endpoints.
tests/services_testing - Test your service functions.

Info.title: Create your Django Rest API
Info.desc: Explains how to create your Django Rest API and connect it to your PostgreSQL database.

Instructions.instruction: Change into your Notes-Rest-Api folder and create the following folders and files. The [Git Repository](https://github.com/MichaelT-W23/Notes-Rest-Api) for this code.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Notes-Rest-Api

mkdir api
mkdir api/errors
mkdir api/models
mkdir api/repositories
mkdir api/routes
mkdir api/schemas
mkdir api/services
mkdir api/utils

mkdir tests
mkdir tests/db_testing
mkdir tests/endpoint_testing
mkdir tests/services_testing

cd api
touch errors/custom_exceptions.py
touch models/db_models.py
touch repositories/note_repository.py
touch repositories/user_repository.py
touch routes/endpoints.py
touch schemas/user_schema.py
touch services/note_service.py
touch services/user_service.py
touch utils/note_verification.py

cd ../tests
touch conftest.py
touch endpoint_testing/test_note_endpoints.py
touch endpoint_testing/test_user_endpoints.py
touch services_testing/test_services.py
touch db_testing/test_db_connection.py

cd ..
touch .gitignore
touch app.py 
touch db.py
touch config.py
Code.CopyCode:
cd Notes-Rest-Api

mkdir api
mkdir api/errors
mkdir api/models
mkdir api/repositories
mkdir api/routes
mkdir api/schemas
mkdir api/services
mkdir api/utils

mkdir tests
mkdir tests/db_testing
mkdir tests/endpoint_testing
mkdir tests/services_testing

cd api
touch errors/custom_exceptions.py
touch models/db_models.py
touch repositories/note_repository.py
touch repositories/user_repository.py
touch routes/endpoints.py
touch schemas/user_schema.py
touch services/note_service.py
touch services/user_service.py
touch utils/note_verification.py

cd ../tests
touch conftest.py
touch endpoint_testing/test_note_endpoints.py
touch endpoint_testing/test_user_endpoints.py
touch services_testing/test_services.py
touch db_testing/test_db_connection.py

cd ..
touch .gitignore
touch app.py 
touch db.py
touch config.py

Instructions.instruction: Push your folder structure to GitHub.

Code.FormatCode:
git add .
git commit -m "Setup Structure"
git push
Code.CopyCode:
git add .
git commit -m "Setup Structure"
git push

Instructions.instruction: Now create a .env file in your folder.
If you initially created a .env file in your first commit, run the following commands so that git won't track it. If you didn't commit a .env file in your first commit, ignore this step.

Code.FormatCode:
git rm .env --cached
git commit -m "Stopped tracking .env File"
git push
Code.CopyCode:
git rm .env --cached
git commit -m "Stopped tracking .env File"
git push

Instructions.instruction: Open the ".gitignore" file in the top-most directory. Paste in the following values.

Info.title: Add Testing to your Flask Rest Api
Info.desc: Explains how to write tests using the pytest framework for your Rest Api.

Instructions.instruction: Open your "Notes-Rest-API" in VSCode. Go to the "tests" folder in the top-most directory. In the "db_testing" folder paste the following code into the "test_db_connection.py" file.

Code.FormatCode:
from db import db
import pytest
from sqlalchemy import text

@pytest.mark.order(5)
def test_database_connection(app):
    with app.app_context():
        result = db.session.execute(text("SELECT * FROM Users LIMIT 1;"))
        first_row = result.fetchone()
        assert first_row is not None, "Database returned no data!"
Code.CopyCode:
from db import db
import pytest
from sqlalchemy import text

@pytest.mark.order(5)
def test_database_connection(app):
    with app.app_context():
        result = db.session.execute(text("SELECT * FROM Users LIMIT 1;"))
        first_row = result.fetchone()
        assert first_row is not None, "Database returned no data!"

Instructions.instruction: In the "endpoint_testing" folder paste the following code into the "test_note_endpoints.py" file.
In the "endpoint_testing" folder paste the following code into the "test_user_endpoints.py" file.
You can test your code by running the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Notes-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate
python3 -m pytest tests/
Code.CopyCode:
cd Notes-Rest-Api
source venv/bin/activate
python3 -m pytest tests/

Instructions.instruction: You can add the -s flag to allow print statements and log output.
You can generate a UI html file for your test results by using the following command.
Open the html report in a browser using the following command.
Push your changes to Github.

Code.FormatCode:
deactivate
git clean -ndX
git add .
git commit -m "Added testing"
git push
Code.CopyCode:
deactivate
git clean -ndX
git add .
git commit -m "Added testing"
git push

Info.title: Angular Website Folder Setup Explanation
Info.desc: Explanation of the folders that will be used for your frontend code.

Instructions.instruction: src/api - Functions used to call and interact with your backend Rest API endpoints. It's a similar concept to the repository functions interacting with the database.
src/assets - Where you'll put things like your pictures, data, etc.
src/components - Components that you can use in your views. An example would a Note card.
src/lib - Where you'll put the link to where your backend Rest API is being hosted. For this project it should probably be something like "http://127.0.0.1:5000" in development.
src/router - The paths of your application. Used to navigate between pages in your application.
src/services - Business logic for your api functions.
src/stores - A management system you can use to store data and methods you can use to modify and interact with it. It's pretty similar to a class.
src/utils - Common functions that are used across various views.
src/views - The pages of your application. The components will be used in these views.
public - Where to store things like videos and files that the user can download

Info.title: Create your Vue Website
Info.desc: Explains how to create your Vue Website and connect it to your Flask Rest API.
